speaker: duncan
dialog: Is execution done on Cawdor? Are not Those in commission yet return'd?

speaker: malcolm
dialog: My liege, They are not yet come back. But I have spoke With one that saw him die: who did report That very frankly he confess'd his treasons, Implored your highness' pardon and set forth A deep repentance.

speaker: malcolm
dialog: nothing in his life Became him like the leaving it; he died As one that had been studied in his death To throw away the dearest thing he owed, As 'twere a careless trifle.

speaker: duncan
dialog: There's no art To find the mind's construction in the face: He was a gentleman on whom I built An absolute trust.

speaker: duncan
dialog: O worthiest cousin! The sin of my ingratitude even now Was heavy on me: thou art so far before That swiftest wing of recompense is slow To overtake thee.

speaker: duncan
dialog: Would thou hadst less deserved, That the proportion both of thanks and payment Might have been mine! only I have left to say, More is thy due than more than all can pay.

speaker: macbeth
dialog: The service and the loyalty I owe, In doing it, pays itself

speaker: macbeth
dialog: Your highness' part Is to receive our duties; and our duties Are to your throne and state children and servants, Which do but what they should, by doing every thing Safe toward your love and honour.

speaker: duncan
dialog: Welcome hither: I have begun to plant thee, and will labour To make thee full of growing.

speaker: duncan
dialog: Noble Banquo, That hast no less deserved, nor must be known No less to have done so, let me enfold thee And hold thee to my heart.

speaker: banquo
dialog: There if I grow, The harvest is your own.

speaker: duncan
dialog: My plenteous joys, Wanton in fulness, seek to hide themselves In drops of sorrow.

speaker: duncan
dialog: Sons, kinsmen, thanes, And you whose places are the nearest, know We will establish our estate upon Our eldest, Malcolm, whom we name hereafter The Prince of Cumberland.

speaker: duncan
dialog: Which honour must Not unaccompanied invest him only, But signs of nobleness, like stars, shall shine On all deservers. From hence to Inverness And bind us further to you.

speaker: macbeth
dialog: The rest is labour, which is not used for you: I'll be myself the harbinger and make joyful The hearing of my wife with your approach; So humbly take my leave.

speaker: duncan
dialog: My worthy Cawdor!

speaker: macbeth
dialog: The Prince of Cumberland! that is a step On which I must fall down, or else o'erleap, For in my way it lies.

speaker: macbeth
dialog: Stars, hide your fires; Let not light see my black and deep desires: The eye wink at the hand; yet let that be, Which the eye fears, when it is done, to see.

speaker: duncan
dialog: True, worthy Banquo; he is full so valiant, And in his commendations I am fed; It is a banquet to me.

speaker: duncan
dialog: Let's after him, Whose care is gone before to bid us welcome: It is a peerless kinsman.
